man. he summoned before him the angels OF
his attributes, the watchers OF his domlnIons
they stood in council round his hidden
throne:


Create him not, said the angel OF Justice
he will no. be equitable to his brethren ne
will Cypress the weaker.


Create him not, said the angel OF peace'
he will manure the soil with human blood
the first born of his race will be the slayer
Of his brother.


Create him not, said the angel OF Truth,
he will defilc thy sanctuary with talsehood'
although thou shouldst stamp on his coun-
tenance, thine image, the seal OF confidence'
So spake the angels of the attributes OF le-
hoyah' when MERCY, the youngest and the

ing his knees, create him. Father, said She
in thy likeness, the darling OF thy loving
kindness; when all thy messengers forsaKe
him. will seek and support him, ana turi
his faults to good. Because he is weak, vii

went off to the kitchen, and the two men to
the barn, which is about two hundred yards
distant The kitchen is only few PAGES from
the room where Lewis was, and the woman
being considerably alarmed, could not sleep,
but listened to him walking backwards and
forwards several hours, and talking aloud as
she said, like lawyer. She ilen heard the
report of pistol, and something fall heavily
OH the floor, and the words Oh Lord I'm
mediatcy afterwards she heard another pis'
tol and in a few moments she heard him call"
ing out-'O madam, give me some WATER
and heal nv wounds The logs being open
and upholstered, she saw him stagger back
and fall against stump that stands between
the kitchen and the room. He c1awied for
some distance, and raised himself by the
side of tree where he sat about minute.
He once more got to the >room---aftcrwards
he came to the kitchen door, but did not
speak--she then heard him .scraping the
bucket with gourd for water-but it ap~
pears this cooling element was denied him


AS soon as the day broke, and not before
(the terror of the woman having permitted
him to remain for two hours in the most de-
plorable situation she sent two of her chill
d1en to the barn, her husband not being
at home, to bring the seryants--and on COM
ing in they found him laying on the bed
He uncovered his side, and showed them
where the bullet had entercd--a piece of his
forehead was blown of, and he had exposed
the brains, without having bed much. He
begged they would take his rife and blow
ont his brains. and he would give them all
the money he had in his trunk. He often


said-'I am no coward--but l am so strong.


SO hard to die!' He begged the servant not


to be afraid of him, for he would not hurt
! him.-He expired in about two hours or just
| as the sun rose above the trees. He lies bu-


ried close by the common path, with few


loose rails thrown over his grave. gave


Grinder money to put fence round it to
shelter it from the hogs and woives-and he
gave me his written promise he would do it,
! left the place in a very melancholy mood


which was not much allayed by the pros
peet Of the gloomy and savage wilderness


which was just entering alone.

Numerous are the passages in the gospel
history, where honorable mention is made
OF the female sex. From the angels saluta.
ton of the virgin mother of our Lord, to the
letter Of John, the beloved apostle, to the la
dy and her children, the New Testament is
iull oftheir exertions, their affection, fidel-
ity and influence. In the course of our Sa-
ylour's ministry, sublime and solemn as was
his supernatural character, we find frequent
examples of his attention to them, and OF
their attachment to him. To the woman of
,samaria, he made the first declaration of
MS Messiahship, and impaired the first
principles of his new and spiritual doctrine.
and this. too, with condescension, which
surprised his disciples, who wondered that
ne talked with the woman. We find him,
also, frequent guest in the family OF Mar
ina and Mary; for Jesus, we are told, loved
Martha, and her sister, and Lazarus One
OF these affectionate sisters to testify her re-
:spect for his person, just before his suffer
inSs, came with box of costly perfume
and poured it over his head, as he sat a
meat; and with so much pleasure did he re
eeWe this offering of female affection, tina
even his disciples murmured, while he de
slafed, that, wherever his gospel wa
preached. it should be told for memoria

THE HOLY WOMEN OF THE NEW TES

TEyery one has heard of Captain Lewis,
the companion Of Clarke in the expeditions
sent BY President JefFerton, to explore our
territory west of the Mississipp-bnt per-
haps few are aware that he perished by sui
eide, in miserable log cabin, far away from
the seats of civilization where his name was
so familiar. The following account IS con
tanned in a letter from Wilson, the ornithol-
oeist, written from Natchez, in the year
1901


Next morning Sunday Irodc six miles,
to a mans of the name OF Grinder, where
our friend Lewis persisted. In the same
room where he expired, took down IRON
Mrs. Grinder, the particulars OF that melan-
choly event, which affected me extremely.
This house or cabin, is twenty-five miles
from Nashville, and is the last white mans
as YOU enter the Indian country.-GoveTnor
Lewis she said, came thither at about sun
set alone, and inquired if he could stay tor
the highland alightng brought his saddle
into the house. He was dressed IN loose
gown, white, striped with blue. On being
asked if he came alone, ne repned that
there were two servants behind who would
soon be up. He called for some spirits, and
drank but very little. When the servants
arrived, one Of whom was negro, he inqur-
| co lot MS JoWuSi, say ms ~ 49, ~


had some powder in canister, The SER
want made no distinct reply. and Lewis IN
the meanwhile, walked to and fro before the
door, talking to h;mself.-Sometimes, she
said. he would seem as if he were walking
up to her-and he would suddenly whee


round, and walk back as fast as he could
Supper being ready, he sat down, but he hat


eaten only few mouthfuls, when he started
up, speaking to himself in violent manner
At these times, she says, she observed M


face to blush, as if it had come on HIM in


fit. He lighted his pipe, and drawing M
chair to the door sat down, saying to Mrs


Grinder, in kind tone of voice-'Madam


this is a very pleasant evening
He smoked for some time, but quilted nj


seat and traversed the yard as before. lie a
gain sat down to his pipe, seemed again com
posed, and casting his eyes wistfully toward
the west observed what a sweetevening II wa
Mrs. Grinder was preparing bed for hlm,bu
he said he would sleep on the foor-and de


sired the servant to bring the bear SKINS an
buffalo robe, which were Immediately sprea


for HINT now being dusk, the woma

Dearest, dry that fearful eye
Dearest, check that mournful sigh;
Lettnot hope thy bosom fly,


Nor sorrow longcr move thee:
For by that pale check swear,
by those eyes of beauty rare.
BY the pure soul shining there


I'll never cease to love thee.


Dearest, dry that fearful eye, sc,
Flowers may cease to bloom in spring,
Birds Of sweetest note to sing,
Storms be horne on Zcphyr's wing,
But none shall rain above thee
In this breast, to which thou'rt dear
As to misery PHYS tear
As to Heaven heart Sincere


And still fondly love thee.


Dearest, dry that fearful eye, Ge.
Ever be thy mind in peace
Ever may thy joys increase;
Love shall make thy anguish cease,
And every hour shall prove thee
sill more dear than in the past
No gloom thy bliss shall overcast
And, by my hopes Of heaven at last,
III ever warmly love thee.

AS approached the Piazza di St. Maria Novel
la,I perceived an unusual crowd and hustle IN
the street, and advanced huriedly to ascertain

TO me on earth My eagre enquiries, a3 to the

the crowd who focked round the place;--A man
inspired with feelings such as those which insti-
gated me, can make his way through any obsta-
clcs. | gained the door; smoke and hames
were pouring through the aperture as from the
crater of Vesuvius ! pulled my bonnet over
my brows, and rushed up the stairs. On the
first landing, the chamber of Beatrice was to
the left-that of her mother to the right. !
turned to the eft--the room was vacant! BE-
gan to hope she had escaped. rushed into the
opposite roon As | entered, stumbled over
something on the hoori It was her body, with that
of her mother in her arms!-She had sunk IN at
tempting to save her. 1t was only now that
perceived the terrible destiny of the smoke to
remove her was the only hope left. In an instant
| bore her through the smoke, and flames, and
crumhling rains into the street.--She was dead!


What were nv feelings Heaven only knows!
III its mercy, it has decrccd that a blow like this
shall numb the heart it crushes. Those who

count ofit; those who have not, can form no idea
il. The first thing which made any impress
ion upon me was fellow student, who was to


inc as a brother, pointing out the effect which
tile indulgence Of my despair had upon my moth
er and sister. ssThey have claims upon you, he
said; ;-sthe nearest, the most holy-ve for
Is, hfe lcfrtt ms
the heart and like most persons whose minds
are shaken by some great sorrow, rushed from

few days since the night, III state OF alternate
despair and stupor could not now restore
myselfto caImness. I needed violent rcsoln-
ton, and formed one determined, II des-

resume my studies at once, and determined to

which the professor was to give.


4 1t was the first time had been in tie fresh cir
since the catastrophe had happened. The state
of tha atmosphere, the aspect OF the heavens
we're precisely similar 20 what thay had been
when looked upon them with her. The clouds
.aclsel over the moon--thc Arno looked dark
aud troubled, md rushed by with moaning
noise. When had last seen these sghts-when

When VIC halted. found myself enclosed
in a dense ring of spectators, i'll the midst
of which stood great brass mortar, raised
on a mound of earth, and beside it, stuck in
the ground, n linstock with a lighted
match. The nussukchees ranged themselves
on each side Of this horrible engine: and it
was with difficulty that succeeded in gain
ing position, which appeared to me to Sc
cure me from the danger attending the ex-
ploeion, and its consequences, when it should
take place. Having taken my station, be-
gan to look around me, and saw the officers
of justice still pouring into the circle, which
was widened for their reception by dint of
blows. After them, or rather between two
of them, came the prisoner. She was en-
vcloped from head to foot, in a black robe,
which also covered her face. Her step was
firm, and her carriage stately. She frc-
quenty spoke few words to an eunuch
who accompanied her; but the noise was so
great that could hear nothing of their dis
course. As she approached, the spectators
became more quiet; and when she reached
the mortar, not sound was to be heard
Taking advantage of the silence, she spoke
aloud, with distinctness and composure
that surprised every one, and made her
words ineligible to all. The officers per-
ceiyng that her wild address made some
impression on the multitude, here interrupt


ed her. She made no attempt TO proceecs
but resigned herself into their arms. They
led her in front of the mortar, and yet her


steps never faltercd; neither did she speak


or implore as is common for even men to do
in her situation; neither did she curse as


some do; neither did she weep. They told
her to kncel down with her breast against
its muzzle, and she did SO. They put cords
round her wrists, and bound them to stakes,


which had been driven for the purpose; still


she showed no signs of emotion; she laid her
head upon the mortar, and waited her fate


with a camposure which soldier might
have envied. At length the signal was givens


the match was raised; it descended slowly


and at the moment when it was about to


touch the powder, an audible shudder ran


through the crowd The printing caught


fire; a moment of sickenng suspense follow


ed; groan burst from the spectators; the


smoke passed away; and no explosion took


place. The unfortunate wretch raised her


head to see what had happened. 4 faint nope


glimmered in my own heart that perhaps
this was a device to save her life, but 1t was


not permitted to live long. 1t had scarcely
begun to rise within me, when saw the
priming renewed, and the match ra'sea a.
gain. The condemned wretch laid her head
once more on its hard pillow, and uttered a


low groan as if her spirit had departed. It


had scarcely been uttered when the eSpio-


sion took nlace. and the smoke covered eve
rv thing from my view. AS it gradually
rlaarrd away, it drew veil from over a
,, horrid and revolving spectacle. The two
,, hodiless a rms hung, with their mangled and
blackrncd ends, from the stakes to which
: they had been bound; and few yards dis
tant Law a scorched and shattered foot and
leg. No trace of body or of head remained
and a few tattered remnants of clothes were
= all besides that were left. The arms were
: unbound from the stakes; and two women
who had issued from the ark at the sound
the explosion, rushed to the spot, seized then


up, and concealing them under their wells
hurried to the Harem with these proofs tina
> the demands of justice had been fulfilled
. Visits 10 the Hureni.

some wealth aud consideration, makes dis

Some of the earliest and most faithful con-
verts Of the apostles, were also from TINS
sex. To the assembled saints and widows,
Peter presented Dorcas aiive. whe mad been
| full of good works and alms.decds, which
she did The tender heart Of Lydia was

Perhaps it is not difficult TO account tor
these frequent examples OF female ChrisIl-
anity, SO interesting, and yet SO honorable 20
the GOSPEL The men in Judea, were LOOK
ine for a prince, as their Messiah, who should
answer their ambitious hopes not only by
tho restoration of the kingdom Of Israel, but
also bv dispensing individual honors and per
sonal distinctions in his approaching domin-
ion. Every Jew, therefore, as he expected
a share Of this splendid power, felt portion
of that vanity, which belongedto the expect,
ed masters Of the world. Hence. they first
approached our Lord with impatience and
high raised hopes: but finding him, contra
ry TO their fancy, SO poor, meek, unpresenh-
inc. spiritual, and unambitious, they often
retired in disgust which, in the great men
of the nation, his rebukes often intiamed TO
rage.


Meanwhile the Jewish women, in their
retired and subordinate station, had little
share in these ambitious expectations ne
mother of Zebedce's children, when she
came TO ask a favor OF Christ, solicited
nothinr for herself, but only tor her sons
that they might have Offices in his kingdom.
To the happiness OF the jewish women u
was of little consequence, whether the stand
ard of the expected universal empire waved
on the temple Of Jerusalem, or the capital AZ
Rome. No wonder, then, they were de-
lighted. when they saw the Christ, the
prince, the idol of the Jewish expectation,
treating their sex with distinguished kind
ness. They were more at leisure to feei
and contemplate the moral greatness OF Je-
sus, the sufferer; while the other sex were
eager to see the sign from Heaven, @h'cn
should mark out Jesus, the triumphant.
The women we're won by the tears @NicN
they saw him shed at the grave OF Lazarus
| in sympathy with the afflicted sisters; but
the men who were standing Dy' "eie u'',
satisfied: ror, said they, could he not have
caused that Lazarus should not have died !!
And when Jesus. the wonder and glory OF
Judea, the suffering prince, cast his last look
from his cross down on the taintng Mary
and says to John with his last breath, "oe-
hold thy mother!'' is il to be wondered at
that the women who stood by and heard 1t
should have begged this body, and embalm-
ed this corpse from which spirit so Affect
ing had just taken its flight!


This regard for the founder OF our faitl
they seemed to have continued to the apos
ties; for the Christian community, IN the mrs.
ages, were distinguished by an order OF wo'
men. who ministered to the necessities o
the saints, who brought up children, lodg-
= ed strangers, who washed the saints feet

!. new the remains of their Lord in the ira
GRANGE of their charities towards the church

The days Of my youth the days of my youth!
how deeply do your recollections dwell with

bright hopes, your burning Wishes your blight
Of heart, your absolute despair. lie who re-

verse ofthc oasis of the desert; for however the
larger portion Of the soul may b,oom--to what
extent soeyer il may be feite--thcre will be al
ways oue spot Of barren and burning waste, to
contrast with and to check the Towering meads
around it.

that smile, which spake of fondness' as tie

part with thee for eyer-aye even tnouSn my

Truly have compared the feelings with which

cles of eartll;---t has all the ETHEREAL purity Of

which enter into the bosom of humanity

cathcdral the water rushed past our feet, a.
though swelled by the torrents from the noun
tans;-but we needed not the gloom; We did no


note the marks of recent tempest; our heart
communed together-,ce were together!
: We parted that night in youth, IN health, II


b;ph hone. For once, ''the course OF true low


Seemed TO run smooth" 1t is true we could no
: vel he united: was as yet only student at 10
;. lorna. and had mother and sister who MANI


depended on my exertions Tor support but u


, few wears my studies would be tinlshedi shonl
: he settled in sphere Of humble usefulness; m
: homes. nv wishes, were fixed on domestic en-


ioyments--on that happiness which is to be tas
:. ed no where but in happy home! 1t is one
: the frequent effects of a strong and vrtuous pa
e sion in early life to accelerate, by many year
i that taste for simple and domestic pleasures
:, which all men feel as they approach the dechn
6 IF wears. have since been wanderer-l hav
e travelled over large portion Of the earthi bu
n if the hopes of my youth had been realized,
Il should have been happy-oh more than hapF
ii in the narrow crcl. around my humble hon

full articles.article:
When the Almighty was about to create
man. he summoned before him the angels OF
his attributes, the watchers OF his domlnIons
they stood in council round his hidden
throne:


Create him not, said the angel OF Justice
he will no. be equitable to his brethren ne
will Cypress the weaker.


Create him not, said the angel OF peace'
he will manure the soil with human blood
the first born of his race will be the slayer
Of his brother.


Create him not, said the angel OF Truth,
he will defilc thy sanctuary with talsehood'
although thou shouldst stamp on his coun-
tenance, thine image, the seal OF confidence'
So spake the angels of the attributes OF le-
hoyah' when MERCY, the youngest and the
dearest child of the Eternal, arose and clasp
ing his knees, create him. Father, said She
in thy likeness, the darling OF thy loving
kindness; when all thy messengers forsaKe
him. will seek and support him, ana turi
his faults to good. Because he is weak, vii
turn m his bowels to compassion, and his sou
70 atooement.-When he departs IRON
pesce. from truth, and from justice, the con
SEQUENCES of his wanderinss shall deter han

went off to the kitchen, and the two men to
the barn, which is about two hundred yards
distant The kitchen is only few PAGES from
the room where Lewis was, and the woman
being considerably alarmed, could not sleep,
but listened to him walking backwards and
forwards several hours, and talking aloud as
she said, like lawyer. She ilen heard the
report of pistol, and something fall heavily
OH the floor, and the words Oh Lord I'm
mediatcy afterwards she heard another pis'
tol and in a few moments she heard him call"
ing out-'O madam, give me some WATER
and heal nv wounds The logs being open
and upholstered, she saw him stagger back
and fall against stump that stands between
the kitchen and the room. He c1awied for
some distance, and raised himself by the
side of tree where he sat about minute.
He once more got to the >room---aftcrwards
he came to the kitchen door, but did not
speak--she then heard him .scraping the
bucket with gourd for water-but it ap~
pears this cooling element was denied him


AS soon as the day broke, and not before
(the terror of the woman having permitted
him to remain for two hours in the most de-
plorable situation she sent two of her chill
d1en to the barn, her husband not being
at home, to bring the seryants--and on COM
ing in they found him laying on the bed
He uncovered his side, and showed them
where the bullet had entercd--a piece of his
forehead was blown of, and he had exposed
the brains, without having bed much. He
begged they would take his rife and blow
ont his brains. and he would give them all
the money he had in his trunk. He often


said-'I am no coward--but l am so strong.


SO hard to die!' He begged the servant not


to be afraid of him, for he would not hurt
! him.-He expired in about two hours or just
| as the sun rose above the trees. He lies bu-


ried close by the common path, with few


loose rails thrown over his grave. gave


Grinder money to put fence round it to
shelter it from the hogs and woives-and he
gave me his written promise he would do it,
! left the place in a very melancholy mood


which was not much allayed by the pros
peet Of the gloomy and savage wilderness


which was just entering alone.

full articles.headline:
THE LADIES' FRIEND.

THE HOLY WOMEN OF THE NEW TES


LAMENT.
full articles.article:
Numerous are the passages in the gospel
history, where honorable mention is made
OF the female sex. From the angels saluta.
ton of the virgin mother of our Lord, to the
letter Of John, the beloved apostle, to the la
dy and her children, the New Testament is
iull oftheir exertions, their affection, fidel-
ity and influence. In the course of our Sa-
ylour's ministry, sublime and solemn as was
his supernatural character, we find frequent
examples of his attention to them, and OF
their attachment to him. To the woman of
,samaria, he made the first declaration of
MS Messiahship, and impaired the first
principles of his new and spiritual doctrine.
and this. too, with condescension, which
surprised his disciples, who wondered that
ne talked with the woman. We find him,
also, frequent guest in the family OF Mar
ina and Mary; for Jesus, we are told, loved
Martha, and her sister, and Lazarus One
OF these affectionate sisters to testify her re-
:spect for his person, just before his suffer
inSs, came with box of costly perfume
and poured it over his head, as he sat a
meat; and with so much pleasure did he re
eeWe this offering of female affection, tina
even his disciples murmured, while he de
slafed, that, wherever his gospel wa
preached. it should be told for memoria

full articles.headline: DEATH OF CAPTAIN LEWIS.
full articles.article:
TEyery one has heard of Captain Lewis,
the companion Of Clarke in the expeditions
sent BY President JefFerton, to explore our
territory west of the Mississipp-bnt per-
haps few are aware that he perished by sui
eide, in miserable log cabin, far away from
the seats of civilization where his name was
so familiar. The following account IS con
tanned in a letter from Wilson, the ornithol-
oeist, written from Natchez, in the year
1901


Next morning Sunday Irodc six miles,
to a mans of the name OF Grinder, where
our friend Lewis persisted. In the same
room where he expired, took down IRON
Mrs. Grinder, the particulars OF that melan-
choly event, which affected me extremely.
This house or cabin, is twenty-five miles
from Nashville, and is the last white mans
as YOU enter the Indian country.-GoveTnor
Lewis she said, came thither at about sun
set alone, and inquired if he could stay tor
the highland alightng brought his saddle
into the house. He was dressed IN loose
gown, white, striped with blue. On being
asked if he came alone, ne repned that
there were two servants behind who would
soon be up. He called for some spirits, and
drank but very little. When the servants
arrived, one Of whom was negro, he inqur-
| co lot MS JoWuSi, say ms ~ 49, ~


had some powder in canister, The SER
want made no distinct reply. and Lewis IN
the meanwhile, walked to and fro before the
door, talking to h;mself.-Sometimes, she
said. he would seem as if he were walking
up to her-and he would suddenly whee


round, and walk back as fast as he could
Supper being ready, he sat down, but he hat


eaten only few mouthfuls, when he started
up, speaking to himself in violent manner
At these times, she says, she observed M


face to blush, as if it had come on HIM in


fit. He lighted his pipe, and drawing M
chair to the door sat down, saying to Mrs


Grinder, in kind tone of voice-'Madam


this is a very pleasant evening
He smoked for some time, but quilted nj


seat and traversed the yard as before. lie a
gain sat down to his pipe, seemed again com
posed, and casting his eyes wistfully toward
the west observed what a sweetevening II wa
Mrs. Grinder was preparing bed for hlm,bu
he said he would sleep on the foor-and de


sired the servant to bring the bear SKINS an
buffalo robe, which were Immediately sprea


for HINT now being dusk, the woma

full articles.headline: DI TANTI PALpITI.
full articles.article:
Dearest, dry that fearful eye
Dearest, check that mournful sigh;
Lettnot hope thy bosom fly,


Nor sorrow longcr move thee:
For by that pale check swear,
by those eyes of beauty rare.
BY the pure soul shining there


I'll never cease to love thee.


Dearest, dry that fearful eye, sc,
Flowers may cease to bloom in spring,
Birds Of sweetest note to sing,
Storms be horne on Zcphyr's wing,
But none shall rain above thee
In this breast, to which thou'rt dear
As to misery PHYS tear
As to Heaven heart Sincere


And still fondly love thee.


Dearest, dry that fearful eye, Ge.
Ever be thy mind in peace
Ever may thy joys increase;
Love shall make thy anguish cease,
And every hour shall prove thee
sill more dear than in the past
No gloom thy bliss shall overcast
And, by my hopes Of heaven at last,
III ever warmly love thee.


Dearest, dry that fearful eye, sc.

the lecture which had been attending--for
had lately devoted much Of my time to the prose-
cnton Of my studies, as celebrated prof, ssor OF
medicine was, at that time, resident in Florence.


AS approached the Piazza di St. Maria Novel
la,I perceived an unusual crowd and hustle IN
the street, and advanced huriedly to ascertain
the cause-for that square held all that was dear
TO me on earth My eagre enquiries, a3 to the
cause of alarm, were speedily answered. When
entered the Piazza, perceived several houses
in hames-her's was one of them! rushed thro'
the crowd who focked round the place;--A man
inspired with feelings such as those which insti-
gated me, can make his way through any obsta-
clcs. | gained the door; smoke and hames
were pouring through the aperture as from the
crater of Vesuvius ! pulled my bonnet over
my brows, and rushed up the stairs. On the
first landing, the chamber of Beatrice was to
the left-that of her mother to the right. !
turned to the eft--the room was vacant! BE-
gan to hope she had escaped. rushed into the
opposite roon As | entered, stumbled over
something on the hoori It was her body, with that
of her mother in her arms!-She had sunk IN at
tempting to save her. 1t was only now that
perceived the terrible destiny of the smoke to
remove her was the only hope left. In an instant
| bore her through the smoke, and flames, and
crumhling rains into the street.--She was dead!


What were nv feelings Heaven only knows!
III its mercy, it has decrccd that a blow like this
shall numb the heart it crushes. Those who
have gone through the ordeal can give no ac
count ofit; those who have not, can form no idea
il. The first thing which made any impress
ion upon me was fellow student, who was to


inc as a brother, pointing out the effect which
tile indulgence Of my despair had upon my moth
er and sister. ssThey have claims upon you, he
said; ;-sthe nearest, the most holy-ve for
Is, hfe lcfrtt ms
the heart and like most persons whose minds
are shaken by some great sorrow, rushed from
one extreme into the other; had ipassed the
few days since the night, III state OF alternate
despair and stupor could not now restore
myselfto caImness. I needed violent rcsoln-
ton, and formed one determined, II des-
pite Of all my friend could say TO dlssuade lnc to
resume my studies at once, and determined to
accompany him that very evening to lecture
which the professor was to give.


4 1t was the first time had been in tie fresh cir
since the catastrophe had happened. The state
of tha atmosphere, the aspect OF the heavens
we're precisely similar 20 what thay had been
when looked upon them with her. The clouds
.aclsel over the moon--thc Arno looked dark
aud troubled, md rushed by with moaning
noise. When had last seen these sghts-when
I had last heard these sounds-shc was by my
side. Oh Gotlt where was she now' Those
who have suffered great affliction can, am
sure full well recall to my mind the impression
of cutting pain, which the contrast between the
present time and few short days before, has
made upon them. Every thing in the external
world, every thing on the surface of society,
seems to be proceeding in its usual tram. NO
length oftime has passed to account Tor SO vast
change; few days only have elapscd-but life
is closed for them one expansc ofimpenetiable
i li,i,o 81. F,t,, SC IN IN


We walked hastily onward-l had no incllna-
ton to loiter on the way We entered the room
lust as the lecture was beginning. 4 crowe! OF
students had gathered round the table On which
the sssubiect'' lay joined them; and having,
by degrees, penetrated the circle, carelessiy
cast my eyes upon the body Whlca lay before
me-It was her'st-The room reeled round with
mel fell senseless!--and there was an idiotc
blank OF forty years in the picture Of my memo
rv

full articles.headline: A PERSIAN EXECUTION.
full articles.article:
When VIC halted. found myself enclosed
in a dense ring of spectators, i'll the midst
of which stood great brass mortar, raised
on a mound of earth, and beside it, stuck in
the ground, n linstock with a lighted
match. The nussukchees ranged themselves
on each side Of this horrible engine: and it
was with difficulty that succeeded in gain
ing position, which appeared to me to Sc
cure me from the danger attending the ex-
ploeion, and its consequences, when it should
take place. Having taken my station, be-
gan to look around me, and saw the officers
of justice still pouring into the circle, which
was widened for their reception by dint of
blows. After them, or rather between two
of them, came the prisoner. She was en-
vcloped from head to foot, in a black robe,
which also covered her face. Her step was
firm, and her carriage stately. She frc-
quenty spoke few words to an eunuch
who accompanied her; but the noise was so
great that could hear nothing of their dis
course. As she approached, the spectators
became more quiet; and when she reached
the mortar, not sound was to be heard
Taking advantage of the silence, she spoke
aloud, with distinctness and composure
that surprised every one, and made her
words ineligible to all. The officers per-
ceiyng that her wild address made some
impression on the multitude, here interrupt


ed her. She made no attempt TO proceecs
but resigned herself into their arms. They
led her in front of the mortar, and yet her


steps never faltercd; neither did she speak


or implore as is common for even men to do
in her situation; neither did she curse as


some do; neither did she weep. They told
her to kncel down with her breast against
its muzzle, and she did SO. They put cords
round her wrists, and bound them to stakes,


which had been driven for the purpose; still


she showed no signs of emotion; she laid her
head upon the mortar, and waited her fate


with a camposure which soldier might
have envied. At length the signal was givens


the match was raised; it descended slowly


and at the moment when it was about to


touch the powder, an audible shudder ran


through the crowd The printing caught


fire; a moment of sickenng suspense follow


ed; groan burst from the spectators; the


smoke passed away; and no explosion took


place. The unfortunate wretch raised her


head to see what had happened. 4 faint nope


glimmered in my own heart that perhaps
this was a device to save her life, but 1t was


not permitted to live long. 1t had scarcely
begun to rise within me, when saw the
priming renewed, and the match ra'sea a.
gain. The condemned wretch laid her head
once more on its hard pillow, and uttered a


low groan as if her spirit had departed. It


had scarcely been uttered when the eSpio-


sion took nlace. and the smoke covered eve
rv thing from my view. AS it gradually
rlaarrd away, it drew veil from over a
,, horrid and revolving spectacle. The two
,, hodiless a rms hung, with their mangled and
blackrncd ends, from the stakes to which
: they had been bound; and few yards dis
tant Law a scorched and shattered foot and
leg. No trace of body or of head remained
and a few tattered remnants of clothes were
= all besides that were left. The arms were
: unbound from the stakes; and two women
who had issued from the ark at the sound
the explosion, rushed to the spot, seized then


up, and concealing them under their wells
hurried to the Harem with these proofs tina
> the demands of justice had been fulfilled
. Visits 10 the Hureni.

full articles.headline: sUNE al, 1877
full articles.article:
from repeating them, and I.shall gently lead
him to amendment.


The Father Of All gave ear, and created
man weak, faltering being, But in his faults,
the pupil of mercy, the son of ever active
and amclierating love--rcmember thine or
igin, then, oh man! when thou art hard and
unknd to thy brother---mercy alone willed
thee to be---love and pity sucked thee at
their busoms.

some wealth aud consideration, makes dis
tinguishcd figure among the friends OF Jc-
sus. She has been most strangely and un-
Justly confounded with that pentent female,
who had been a sinner, and who bathed our
Lords feet with tears OF contrition. but
Mary Madalenc had been cured by our Sa-
viour of one of the most terrible maladies.
which can inhict our suffering nature, and
the fondest employment o. her recovered
reason seemst TO have 5ecn, 10 listen TO her
aeivcrer, aud to minister to him OF her sub
stance. With many ofthe women she follow
ed him from Galilee thro' that scene OF suffer
ing, when all the disciples from our sex for
sock him and fed The womenneverl lost sight
of him, till he WAS raised upon the cross
then they stood by and witnessed his expir-
ing moments. They left not the body till it
was deposited in the tomb; then they saw
where it was laid, and prepared their spices
to embalm it. On the Sabbath they were
obliged to leave it. and rest, according to
the commandment; but their wake!ul eyes
caught the first streak OF eastern light on
the morning of the resurrection; and to the
women. watching and weeping at the sePul-
chrc, appeared the first delightful vision OF
the Lord Of glory, risen in all the freshness
Of his new and immortal life.


Some of the earliest and most faithful con-
verts Of the apostles, were also from TINS
sex. To the assembled saints and widows,
Peter presented Dorcas aiive. whe mad been
| full of good works and alms.decds, which
she did The tender heart Of Lydia was
melted al the preaching Of Paul; and. IN his
epstlcs, he seldom fails to send salutatlons
to some of those excellent females, who, ny
their works OF charity and labors OF love,
| cherished tho feeble community OF pcrsccnt-
ed Christians. and illustrated the amlablc
spirit and bcnignant influence Of the religion
they professcd.


Perhaps it is not difficult TO account tor
these frequent examples OF female ChrisIl-
anity, SO interesting, and yet SO honorable 20
the GOSPEL The men in Judea, were LOOK
ine for a prince, as their Messiah, who should
answer their ambitious hopes not only by
tho restoration of the kingdom Of Israel, but
also bv dispensing individual honors and per
sonal distinctions in his approaching domin-
ion. Every Jew, therefore, as he expected
a share Of this splendid power, felt portion
of that vanity, which belongedto the expect,
ed masters Of the world. Hence. they first
approached our Lord with impatience and
high raised hopes: but finding him, contra
ry TO their fancy, SO poor, meek, unpresenh-
inc. spiritual, and unambitious, they often
retired in disgust which, in the great men
of the nation, his rebukes often intiamed TO
rage.


Meanwhile the Jewish women, in their
retired and subordinate station, had little
share in these ambitious expectations ne
mother of Zebedce's children, when she
came TO ask a favor OF Christ, solicited
nothinr for herself, but only tor her sons
that they might have Offices in his kingdom.
To the happiness OF the jewish women u
was of little consequence, whether the stand
ard of the expected universal empire waved
on the temple Of Jerusalem, or the capital AZ
Rome. No wonder, then, they were de-
lighted. when they saw the Christ, the
prince, the idol of the Jewish expectation,
treating their sex with distinguished kind
ness. They were more at leisure to feei
and contemplate the moral greatness OF Je-
sus, the sufferer; while the other sex were
eager to see the sign from Heaven, @h'cn
should mark out Jesus, the triumphant.
The women we're won by the tears @NicN
they saw him shed at the grave OF Lazarus
| in sympathy with the afflicted sisters; but
the men who were standing Dy' "eie u'',
satisfied: ror, said they, could he not have
caused that Lazarus should not have died !!
And when Jesus. the wonder and glory OF
Judea, the suffering prince, cast his last look
from his cross down on the taintng Mary
and says to John with his last breath, "oe-
hold thy mother!'' is il to be wondered at
that the women who stood by and heard 1t
should have begged this body, and embalm-
ed this corpse from which spirit so Affect
ing had just taken its flight!


This regard for the founder OF our faitl
they seemed to have continued to the apos
ties; for the Christian community, IN the mrs.
ages, were distinguished by an order OF wo'
men. who ministered to the necessities o
the saints, who brought up children, lodg-
= ed strangers, who washed the saints feet
who relieved the afflicted, and diligently fol
lowed every good work, thus embamlng
!. new the remains of their Lord in the ira
GRANGE of their charities towards the church
i which is his body.

EMNfAUS--A sAcnLp oDE.
abide ,rith ts. for il is totrards ereaing."


Luxe xiv. 29
.fJ;1e Nth as, the evening shades
Begln already to prevail;
And as the lingering twilight fades.
Dark clouds along the horizon sail.
abide wifh us--thc night is chill,
And damp and cheerlcss IS the ali:
BE our companion, stranger, still,
And thy rcposc shall be cur care
.qJide ,pih us--thy converse sweet
Has we'll beguiled the tedious way
With such a friend We JOY to meet,
we supplicate thy longer stay.
.q6ide uiM Qs-for we'll we know
Thy skill to cheer the gloomy hour;
Like balm thy honicd accents flow,
our wounded spirits feel their power.
.?jtde Nth us--and still unfold
Thy sacred, thy prophetic love;
What wond'rous things ofJesus told!
Stranger, we thirst, we pant for moro.
.lbiae with us---and still converse
Of him, who late on Calvary died
Of him, the prophecies rehearse,
He was our friend they cruciiicd.
abide pith us--our hearts arc cold,
We thought that Israel he'd restore;
But sweet the truths thy lips have told,
And, stranger, we complain no more.
.qbidc Uith uS--we feel the charm


That binds us to our unknown friend;
Here pass the night secure from harm,
Here, stranger, let thy wanderings end.
abide apih us--to their request


The stranger bows, with smiles divine;
Then round the board the unknown guest
And weary travellers recline.
.7bide NTH us-amazed they cry,


As suddenly, whilst breaking bread,
Their own lost Jesus meets their eye,
With radiant glory on his head
.i5ide with us--thou heavenly friend,
Leave not thy followers thus alone,
The sweet communion here must end,
The heavenly visitant is gone!

full articles.headline:
LOVES LAST MEETING.

HolorAa
full articles.article:
(Modernzcd from an old Manuscript found


among the Records ofthc Medical School at


Bologaa)


The days Of my youth the days of my youth!
how deeply do your recollections dwell with
in my soull-how wildly does memory recall
YOU, and the deeds to which YOU gave rise! your
bright hopes, your burning Wishes your blight
Of heart, your absolute despair. lie who re-
cciyes stunning blow early in life, will lprofably
through physical strength, rise, after time,
from under it; and, ifhc be thrown into full COL
lission with the world, the wound will heal over,
though from time to tune, the scar whichit leaves
will ache. In his breast there will be the re-
verse ofthc oasis of the desert; for however the
larger portion Of the soul may b,oom--to what
extent soeyer il may be feite--thcre will be al
ways oue spot Of barren and burning waste, to
contrast with and to check the Towering meads
around it.


Oh, Florence! thou whted sepalchre OF out
war! bcautv--thou nwatd ci,incl house Of III
4 nv happiness-of my souis hopes!--how bitter
lv do | hate what others love so much--thy
streets of palaces, and thy tlowiig Arno With
what a lcaden heart have looked down. from thy
surrounding ampitheltre Of hills, upon thy far
| villas, glittering among the dassy olives; and
thy noble church, rising like crown to complete
this scene Of queenly beauty! What, indeed,
is tie loyencss Of natural object, II the asso-
Citations connected with it be sad II the IT,
dings be mourniul, ot what avail is the speakers
voice,


I When went again to Florence, after long
years, it was recalling into new life the great inc
one misfortune Of my youth. Ny heart beat a.
Cainst my side with the tulnnltuous throb OF re-
awakening agony; felt once more the desola-
ton ofa buried spirit. Alas! how strong are the
! gIfE
cane over me asI passed the house where -


Beauty bealned upon her brow-Lovc flashed
| from her eyes, and inantled on her glowing lips,
III. full confidence and utter unreserve ofyounS
affection, gave TO lcr the dignity Of their own sin
pleness and simplicity. What, indeed is more
holy than female love in its first force and purl-
ty-beforc the world has chilled it, or repetition
snllicd the exquisite bloom Of its unity and a.
bandonment! 1t is one Of the highest and most
intense Of the mysteries of human nature--one
of the most beautiful of its Phenoinena--the
most engrossing Of its impulses! The soPhisti-
Gated NAV sneer at its simple fcelings-the cor
rupt NAV mistake its purity for GOODNESS; out tilat
yey simplicity is the cause, at once, and the ei-
fcct of its strength and condensation: the very
nurity of the flame betokens its immense heat!


How beautiful she was!-Hcautyt oh, beauty
which mal's the scnscs drunk, and the spirits
reel under thy inhuence-whlch like the Wild
Ihoney of the ancient story, art delicious 10 the
taste, but maddening to the brah.--hoW thy
force and thy sweetness, are they not increased


when we behold thee in the woman OF our soul 5
loye Here is her picture! How lovely are their
features!-their fine outlnc--tliclr rich devel-
opement--their placid expression iioW inc
